text.p: - Officers in cash-strapped Russian anti-aircraft defence units in the Far East have been ordered to look for part-time jobs.

- Journalists accredited at a cardiological conference in Moscow, which included doctors who will decide when and where President Boris Yeltsin will undergo heart surgery, outnumbered participants by two to one.
- Antique manuscripts worth at least $400,000 were stolen in a meticulously prepared and executed burglary from a Moscow library.
- Whether he needs it or not, President Yeltsin must now undergo heart surgery for political reasons, to prove he is fit for the presidency.
- Russian Duma deputies are planning to soften the 1997 budget considerably, leaving a loophole for higher inflation.
- Naina Yeltsin is expected to stay in the Central Clinical Hospital in Moscow, where her husband is being prepared for heart surgery, for as long as it takes doctors to set a date for his operation.
- The upper chamber of the Russian parliament may prove a stumbling block for the 1997 budget as regional leaders expect more money for their needs then currently envisaged.
- Organisers of Michael Jackson's recent concert in Moscow suffered substantial losses as they managed to sell only about a half the seats at the event.
